New data shows that many people in Europe are hesitant about getting the AstraZeneca vaccine due to concerns about its safety. In Germany, 27% of people said they would refuse the vaccine and wait for a different one, while in France and Italy the numbers were 22% and 23% respectively. Spain had the lowest percentage at 19%, while in the UK only 2% expressed hesitancy towards the AstraZeneca vaccine. Pfizer had the lowest hesitation rates across all countries, with only 6-7% of people saying they would refuse it. Moderna also had relatively low hesitation rates, with 11-12% of people refusing it in Germany, France, and Italy.

We're talking about a really impressive woman named Dr. Kizzmekia Corbett. She's a lead scientist at the National Institute of Health (NIH), which is a fancy way of saying she's really smart and knows a lot about science. 

Dr. Corbett has been working to help stop the coronavirus by developing a vaccine. She worked specifically on the vaccine made by a company called Moderna. 

But get this: Dr. Corbett has actually been studying similar viruses like SARS and MERS since way back in 2014. That means she's been preparing for something like COVID-19 for a really long time! 

Overall, Dr. Corbett is doing amazing work and is a really important figure in women's history.

"Understanding COVID-19 Vaccines: A Q&A with UNICEF Sudan's Supply and Logistics Officer"

In this article, we hear from Amna Osman, Supply and Logistics Officer at UNICEF Sudan, about the supply side of COVID-19 vaccines. UNICEF is working alongside organizations such as Gavi and CEPI to ensure that vaccines are delivered quickly and efficiently to those in need.

Osman answers common questions about the distribution process, including how vaccines are transported, stored, and distributed to remote areas. She also discusses the challenges facing vaccine distribution in Sudan, including the need to navigate difficult terrain and reach marginalized communities.

Overall, this Q&A provides valuable insight into the complex logistics of vaccinating populations against COVID-19, particularly in developing countries like Sudan.

The article discusses what we do and don't know about Covid-19 and vaccines. There are still some uncertainties surrounding the virus and the efforts to combat it. As COVID vaccines become more widely available, many people are wondering if getting vaccinated will affect their COVID testing results. Here are 5 common questions people may have about testing after getting a COVID vaccine: 

1) Will the vaccine cause me to test positive for COVID? No, getting vaccinated should not make you test positive for COVID on a viral test.

2) Will the vaccine affect my antibody test results? Yes, the vaccine can lead to positive antibody test results, but getting a positive result does not necessarily mean you are immune to COVID.

3) How long should I wait after getting vaccinated to get tested? If you have COVID symptoms, you should get tested right away, even if you just got vaccinated. However, it is recommended that you wait at least a few weeks after your final vaccine dose to get an antibody test.

4) Will the vaccine affect the accuracy of COVID tests? No, the vaccine should not affect the accuracy of viral or antibody COVID tests.

5) Do I still need to get tested if I have been vaccinated? It is possible to still contract and spread COVID even after being vaccinated, so it is important to follow public health guidelines and get tested if you have symptoms or have been in close contact with someone with COVID.

Can pregnant women and nursing mothers get the COVID-19 vaccine? Many people are wondering about the potential effects of the vaccine on these groups. According to recent studies and guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the vaccine appears to be safe for most pregnant and breastfeeding women.

However, the decision to get vaccinated is ultimately up to the individual and should be made in consultation with a healthcare provider. Pregnant women who do choose to get vaccinated should be aware of the potential side effects, which can include fever, sore arm, and fatigue. These side effects are a normal response to the vaccine and are not harmful to the baby.

In addition, it's important to note that there is limited data on the vaccine's effects on pregnant and breastfeeding women, so more research is needed. However, the available evidence suggests that the benefits of vaccination outweigh the risks for most people.

Overall, if you are pregnant or breastfeeding and considering the COVID-19 vaccine, it's important to talk with your doctor and make an informed decision.

Here are some possible rewrites of this article to make it more understandable:

1. Three Medical Breakthroughs Inspired by Covid-19 That Will Last Beyond the Pandemic
- Scientists have developed new genetic vaccines that use a virus's own DNA or RNA to train the immune system to fight infections.
- Wearable devices like fitness trackers and smartwatches are being used to monitor people's health remotely and detect early signs of illness.
- Covid-19 has also spurred advances in drug discovery, as researchers search for new treatments and therapies to combat the virus.

2. Three Ways Covid-19 Has Changed the Medical Landscape Forever
- Genetic vaccines are a new type of vaccine that use genetic material from a pathogen to stimulate the immune system. These vaccines have shown promise in fighting Covid-19 and could be used to prevent other diseases in the future.
- Wearable technology has become increasingly popular during the pandemic, as people use fitness trackers and other devices to monitor their health and detect early signs of illness.
- The search for Covid-19 treatments has led to breakthroughs in drug discovery, with researchers developing new drugs and therapies to fight the virus. Additionally, telehealth has emerged as a way to provide remote medical care during the pandemic.

3. How Covid-19 Has Accelerated Medical Innovation in Three Key Areas
- Genetic vaccines, which use snippets of genetic material to train the immune system, have been developed in record time to combat Covid-19.
- Wearable technology has been used to monitor people's health remotely during the pandemic and could revolutionize healthcare in the future.
- Covid-19 has spurred advances in drug discovery, as researchers develop new treatments and therapies to combat the virus. In addition, telehealth has become increasingly popular as a way to provide medical care without risking exposure to the virus.

COVID-19: A Nurse's Sensible Advice

Many people are being told to practice good hand washing, personal hygiene, and social distancing to avoid getting the coronavirus. However, there is not much advice available on what to do if you do catch it. This is something a lot of people are concerned about.

As a nurse, I have seen many cases of COVID-19. That is why I think it is important to share some sensible advice on what to do if you catch the virus. 

Firstly, do not panic. The majority of people who get COVID-19 will recover at home. Only a small number of people will require hospitalization. 

If you are sick, stay home and self-isolate. This means not leaving your home for anything other than medical care. Separate yourself from others in your household, if possible. 

Stay hydrated and get plenty of rest. You can take over-the-counter medications to help with symptoms, but make sure to follow the recommended dosage. Avoid taking ibuprofen, as it may increase your risk of complications.

Monitor your symptoms and seek medical attention if they get worse. Pay attention to symptoms such as shortness of breath, chest pain, or confusion. 

In conclusion, while it is important to take preventative measures to avoid COVID-19, it is equally important to have a plan in place in case you do become infected. Remember to stay calm, self-isolate, rest, and seek medical attention if needed.
